Rafael, sorry I sent my previous reply before I saw this post.

Perhaps the=
 best way to say it is that behaviors that reach the goal
should not be con=
flated by the novelty metric with behaviors that do
not reach the goal.  To=
 the extent that is true, the setup will allow
novelty to potentially reach=
 the goal, even though the goal is never
explicitly specified to the algori=
thm.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Rafael C.P." <kurama.youko.br@...>=
 wrote:
>
> Hi Joel,
> What I'm saying about the embedding is that there's =
a high degree of
> correlation between the specific chosen novelty function=
 and an
objective
> function that measures distance from the goal, because =
in many cases
(not
> all of them, for sure), specifically in this experimen=
t, higher novelty
> values would mean higher fitness too. I think your answ=
er was
accurate and
> shows what I was trying to say: you still need to thi=
nk in terms of
> objectives when modeling the novelty function, and need a =
binary
objective
> function too, as you said. My point is that it's not a 1=
00% pure novelty
> approach, but it's a good thing, because a 100% pure nov=
elty approach
> probably wouldn't work (it would be like a binary search wi=
thin a
> high-dimensional space without knowing when to go "left" or "right=
",
going
> to the center of the biggest partition until the solution is fou=
nd).
> 
> On Wed, May 14, 2008 at 4:47 PM, joel278 <lehman.154@...> wrote:
=
> 
> >   Rafael,
> >
> > What you are saying is true -- if you are interest=
ed in finding a
> > specific behavior with novelty search, then you need to=
 design the
> > novelty measure so that the behavior of interest is distinc=
t from
> > other behaviors. If the goal behavior is not differentiated from=

> > initial behaviors than performance will likely be poor, because any
> =
> navigator that came close to the goal behavior would be *penalized* by
> =
> novelty search rather than rewarded (since this behavior would not be
> >=
 seen as novel).
> >
> > So the novelty metric is very important when it co=
mes to biasing the
> > search, and should "recognize" the goal behavior and=
 not conflate it
> > with non-goal behaviors.
> >
> > For example, in the m=
aze navigation domain, if the novelty measure was
> > "how much does a navi=
gator rotate during an evaluation", then we would
> > expect to find naviga=
tors with various spinning behaviors, but there
> > is no reason to expect =
navigators to fully navigate the maze; that is
> > because rotation is not =
correlated with any exploratory movement
> > within the maze. In addition, =
a navigator that reached the goal (and
> > rotated x degrees while doing so=
) would appear the same as a navigator
> > that sat at the initial location=
 and spun x degrees.
> >
> > This goal/non-goal conflation is an example of=
 harmful conflation, and
> > a way of combating it is to simply provide mor=
e information (or more
> > relevant information) in the behavioral characte=
rization of an
> > individual. It is not always obvious what the most relev=
ant
> > information is for a given domain, e.g. in biped walking, although =
one
> > can usually make an informed hypothesis - for example, the final
> =
> location of a biped walker after an evaluation may differentiate
> > a su=
ccessful walker from a biped that cannot walk (because a
> > successful wal=
ker will travel further), whereas using the angle of a
> > biped's head as =
a novelty measure will probably not be effective since
> > head angle proba=
bly has no relation to behaviors of interest.
> >
> > However, I don't thin=
k it is accurate to say that the objective
> > function is embedded within =
novelty search; novelty search searches
> > only for novel behaviors, ignor=
ing any notion of better and worse with
> > respect to the goal. I think wh=
at you are saying is that you still
> > have to have some criteria for term=
ination (i.e. a routine that
> > recognizes a successful individual).
> >
>=
 > It is important to differentiate an objective function that provides a
>=
 > gradient towards *better* individuals that is used in typical
> > approa=
ches from a binary "have we found the goal yet" function that
> > does not =
actively bias the search. One of the key arguments in the
> > paper is that=
 the bias of the objective function often keeps search
> > from reaching th=
e goal.
> >
> > Joel
> >
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <neat%40yahoog=
roups.com>, "Rafael C.P." <
> > kurama.youko.br@> wrote:
> > >
> > > But di=
dn't the agent reached the goal just because the goal is very
> > > differe=
nt from the start position? It's like the objective
function was
> > > embe=
dded in the novelty function. If the goal was similar to the
start
> > > po=
sition in novelty space, it probably would perform worse than
random
> > > =
search. But anyway, I think the agent couldn't stop searching by
> > itself=
 when
> > > reached the goal unless you told him to stop there, 'cause he w=
ould
> > still
> > > try novel behaviors after that.
> > >
> > > On Wed, Ma=
y 14, 2008 at 2:39 PM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@>
> >
> > > wrote:
> > >
>=
 > > > Peter, there is no indication that the maze solvers produced by
> > =
> > novelty search are any less "smart" than those produced by
> > > > fitn=
ess-based search. As we mention in the paper briefly under
> > > > "Typical=
 Solution," solutions from both methods just go
straight to
> > > > the goa=
l. In other words, they do not take meandering paths; they
> > > > take the=
 most rational path and appear goal-oriented. So there
is no
> > > > discer=
nible quality difference.
> > > >
> > > > However, it's an interesting issu=
e because it gets to the
question of
> > > > what it means to be smart vs. =
lucky. In general, if an animal
has a
> > > > behavior that gets the job do=
ne consistently, one could say
the animal
> > > > just "happens" to do the =
right thing, or one could say the
animal is
> > > > "smart." In fact, I thi=
nk these are one and the same and the
> > > > distinction does not really a=
dd insight into the inner workings
> > > > of the animal's mind.
> > > >
> =
> > > One of the reasons we get stuck on the issue of whether
something is
=
> > > > "really" smart is because of the allure of the adaptive
hypothesis =
in
> > > > evolutionary theory: We try to explain everything we see in
natu=
re in
> > > > terms of some kind of adaptation, and as soon as you assume
t=
hat what
> > > > you are seeing is the result of an adaptation, you are
sus=
ceptible to
> > > > the idea that it must be "good" in some way (which equa=
tes to
"smart"
> > > > when decision-making is at issue). Yet what novelty =
search
shows is
> > > > that a non-adaptive process can in many cases produ=
ce equivalent
> > > > behaviors, which really turns the adaptive hypothesis=

upside-down, and
> > > > makes the interpretation of the "value" of a beha=
vior more
confusing.
> > > > Yet at the end of the day, if it works it work=
s, regardless of
why it
> > > > became the way it did.
> > > >
> > > > Anyw=
ay, so on the question of time series, I would not be
concerned
> > > > wit=
h this issue of whether it is really smart. However, another
> > > > consid=
eration is whether there is sufficient domain constraint
to make
> > > > th=
is search something other than exhaustive enumeration. Novelty
> > > > sear=
ch relies on the properties of the domain (i.e. the
environment)
> > > > to=
 create a useful landscape for the search. Something without any
> > > > en=
vironmental constraint may not make a good search space. So for
> > > > exa=
mple searching through all possible pictures hoping to find
Mona
> > > > Li=
sa one day may not be a good idea because just about
anything you do
> > > =
> genetically produces something "novel." In other words, there
is no
> > >=
 > "collapse" of multiple genetic points into fewer novelty
points (or
> > =
> > more accurately, there may not be cases of novelty points
clustered
> >=
 > > closer together in behavior space than the corresponding
genomes in
> =
> > > genome space).
> > > >
> > > > Still, I am not sure about time series=
, because the
distribution of
> > > > input precursor series may be thought=
 of as a kind of constraint,
> > > > since there are some precursor series =
you would never see. So
it may
> > > > actually work...I'm not sure, but it=
's an interesting possibility.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > ken
> > > >
> > > > =

2D maze

hat a

robot

cident?
How much
> > > > > this depends upon the environment and the inputs=
 provided?
Is it the
> > > > > same with fitness-based search? I am asking =
this because I
am about
> > > > > to introduce novelty search to time serie=
s forecasting which
is very
> > > > > complex domain in terms of characteri=
zing behavior.
> > > > >
> > > > > Peter
> > > > >

hoogroups.com <neat%40yahoogroups.com> <neat%
> > 40yahoogroups.com>, "Kenn=
eth

> > > > > >

's message brings up another issue that might be
useful to
> > > > > > Pete=
r B: For ambulation, it might be more effective to use
leaky
> > > > > > in=
tegrator neurons than the usual feedforward neurons that are
> > used
> > >=
 > > in
> > > > > > most ANN models. The leaky integrators are better for p=
recise
> > > > > timing.
> > > > > > However, they may not be necessary if =
joint angles are being
> > > > > provided
> > > > > > as input. But when jo=
int angles are not provided, I do not
think I
> > > > > > have ever seen a =
regular recurrent ANN (i.e. non-leaky or
not some
> > > > > > other special=
 type of neuron) be able to make something
walk. In
> > > > > > fact, the "=
flailing" motions are often reduced
significantly by
> > > > > leaky
> > > =
> > > integrator neurons. Tyler Streeter saw this when he worked
on his
> >=

> > switchi=
ng to
> > > > > > leaky integrators. However, in his project the network ha=
d no

ern generation.

> > > > > > > to

<neat%
> > 40yahoogroups.com>, "Kenneth
> >
> > > > S=
tanley" <kstanley@>
> > > > > wrote:
> > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > Hi=
 Peter, that's a good question and of course
learning to
> > > > > > > cont=
rol a
> > > > > > > > > virtual creature with novelty search is a
complicat=
ed issue
> > > > > (and
> > > > > > > an
> > > > > > > > > appealing idea a=
s well).
> > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > First, you have to deal with a=
ll the
representational and
> > > > > > > physical
> > > > > > > > > issues=
 outside of novelty search, like how many
inputs, how
> > > > > many
> > > =
> > > > > > outputs, and whether the body itself is not physically
> > flaw=
ed
> > > > > in
> > > > > > > > > some way (which is possible). As you are
=
experiencing, the
> > > > > > > > > inputs/outputs issue can be prohibitive=
 even with
feature
> > > > > > > > > selection. It is also possible that Hy=
perNEAT could be
> > > > > useful
> > > > > > > > > because it does not car=
e about the # inputs or
outputs (and
> > > > > can
> > > > > > > > > potent=
ially exploit geometric regularities), but
configuring
> > > > > the
> > > =
> > > > > > substrate then becomes the challenge.
> > > > > > > > >
> > > >=
 > > > > > Assuming all of that stuff is set up well with whatever
> > > > =
> system,
> > > > > > > then
> > > > > > > > > novelty search is a potentia=
lly winning approach.
Yet as you
> > > > > > > point
> > > > > > > > > out =
there are some big questions there as well. In
fact, we
> > > > > are
> > >=
 > > > > > > currently trying to provide the best answers to these
> > > > =
> questions
> > > > > > > in
> > > > > > > > > ongoing research, but some g=
eneral principles might
help for
> > > > > now:
> > > > > > > > >
> > > > >=
 > > > > First, the archive in novelty search does not not
need to
> > > > =
> contain
> > > > > > > > > every point ever visited. Therefore, it tends t=
o
grow much
> > > > > > > slower
> > > > > > > > > than the #of evaluations=
. However, if it is indeed
getting
> > > > > too
> > > > > > > big
> > > > =
> > > > > then it is not unreasonable to collapse some of the
archive
> > >=
 > > > > points,
> > > > > > > > > although there is no standard method yet=
 for how
that should
> > > > > be
> > > > > > > > > done. But we have reaso=
n to believe there will be
effective
> > > > > and
> > > > > > > > > simple=
 ways to do that.
> > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > Second, the issue of =
one individual looking
different just
> > > > > > > because
> > > > > > > >=
 > of a phase difference in effectivley the same
behavior is
> > > > > > > =
> > complicated. For certain phase disaparities, the two
> > > > > individu=
als
> > > > > > > > > won't look all that different, but it is true that
at=
 some
> > > > > > > > > disparity, they may look very different. Yet it is
=
not clear
> > > > > > > > > whether that fact is actually problematic to th=
e novelty
> > > > > search
> > > > > > > or
> > > > > > > > > not, because =
it would simply reward both types of
behavior.
> > > > > It
> > > > > > > i=
s
> > > > > > > > > possible that the phase difference is a result of some
=
> > useful
> > > > > > > > > genotypic change, which could make it a steppi=
ng
stone to
> > > > > > > something
> > > > > > > > > better. Or, it is pos=
sible that it is superfluous
> > > > > information
> > > > > > > and
> > > =
> > > > > > simply takes some extra time exploring the area
around the
> > =
> > > phase-
> > > > > > > > > shifted individual. So it is hard to say a p=
riori
whether it
> > > > > is
> > > > > > > a
> > > > > > > > > major conce=
rn. We will have better answers to such
questions
> > > > > as
> > > > > > =
> the
> > > > > > > > > technique is further explored.
> > > > > > > > >
> =
> > > > > > > > However, I agree that it would be nice to be able to
say th=
e
> > > > > two
> > > > > > > > > phase-shifted individuals are largely the=
 same if
that is
> > > > > indeed
> > > > > > > > > what you want to say. A=
nd for that, you would need a
> > pattern-
> > > > > > > > > matching metri=
c to compute behavioral distance, i.e.
> > > > > something
> > > > > > > mo=
re
> > > > > > > > > sophisiticated than simple Cartesian distance. There a=
re
> > > > > > > certainly
> > > > > > > > > such metrics available. Howeve=
r, it's important to
recognize
> > > > > > > that
> > > > > > > > > it is n=
ot evident at this point that ignoring the phase
> > shift
> > > > > is
> >=
 > > > > > > > actually better than taking it into consideration,
because
>=
 > > > > taking
> > > > > > > it
> > > > > > > > > into consideration just =
means adding more
information to the
> > > > > > > novelty
> > > > > > > > =
> landscape.
> > > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > > So overall I think novelty=
 search is a very promising
> > > > > direction
> > > > > > > to
> > > > > =
> > > > go for such problems, but it is still in the realm of
> > > > > res=
earch
